isis.stitle: DT-466E and 530E Diesel Engine Diagnostics Model Years 1999-2000 - MECHANICAL DIAGNOSTICS - HARD START / NO START DIAGNOSTICS - EST Data List

svcsubproc.title: Purpose
svcsubproc.para: To determine if starting components meet operating specifications.

warning.para: Read all safety instructions in this manual before doing this procedure.

note.para: Make sure batteries are fully charged before doing this test.

step1.para: Connect the EST tool to the American Trucking Association (ATA) diagnostic connector.

note.para: If an EST is not available, use a Digital Volt Ohm Meter (DMM) to do the following tests:

item.para: ECM Voltage Test (Test 10)
Engine Cranking Test (Test 11)
Injection Control Pressure Test (Test 12)

step1.para: Turn ignition switch ON. Do not start the engine.
Crank engine and read Electronic Service Tool (EST) to measure battery voltage, engine cranking rpm, and Injection Control Pressure (ICP).

item.para: The battery voltage must be 7 or more volts. If voltage to the Electronic Control Module (ECM) drops below 7 volts, the ECM will not remain powered up. If the ECM does not get power through the ECM relay, the engine will not start.

Engine cranking speed must generate the required ICP to operate the fuel injectors and create required compression to ignite the fuel. If the EST shows 0 rpm during engine cranking, the ECM may not be receiving a signal from the Camshaft Position (CMP) sensor. If the CMP sensor is not functioning, it must be replaced. The ECM will not allow the Injection Pressure Regulator (IPR) valve to fully activate without a CMP signal. See CMP sensor diagnostics in Electronic Control System Diagnostics, section 3.
If the EST indicates low or no injection control pressure, check oil in oil reservoir (on front cover) as follows:
1.Remove the engine harness connector from the Engine Oil Temperature (EOT) sensor.
2. Remove the EOT sensor from the front cover. Oil should drain from the internal reservoir.
3.Refill the reservoir and reinstall EOT sensor and harness connector.

note.para: If the oil reservoir level continues to fall, the primary lube oil pump may no be supplying adequate oil to the OIL reservoir.

item.para: Low battery voltage: Failed batteries, high resistance at battery cable connections or in wiring to the ECM.
Defective ECM power relay
Blown 40A in-line fuse (in battery box) which supplies voltage to the ECM
Low cranking rpm: Electrical system malfunctions, incorrect oil, or long oil change intervals in cold ambient temperatures.

No rpm indication on the EST while cranking the engine: Faulty CMP sensor or circuitry to the ECM. Recheck Diagnostic Trouble Codes after cranking engine. See EST, Diagnostic Trouble Codes or STI Diagnostic Trouble Codes.
Low ICP Pressure: A leak in the high pressure oil system or a defective ICP sensor.
Defective high pressure oil pump or pump drive
Defective Injection Pressure Regulator (IPR) or electronic controls for the regulator
Electronic Service Tool (EST) with Master Diagnostics software
Low voltage at ECM: See ECM PWR, Electronic Control Module Power Circuit in, Electronic Control System Diagnostics, section 3.
No Engine rpm indication during engine cranking: See CMP sensor diagnostics in Section 3, Electronic Control System Diagnostics.
No Injection Control Pressure: See Injection Control Pressure (ICP) sensor and IPR valve diagnostics in Section 3, Electronic Control System Diagnostics.
No or low injection control pressure and no electronic Diagnostic Trouble Codes: See ECM Voltage Test (Test 10).
